LAW 12-210 "Child Support and Welfare Reform Compliance Temporary Amendment Act of 1998" Pursuant to Section 412 of the District of Columbia Self-Government and Governmental Reorganization Act, P.L. 93-198 "the Act the Council of the District of Columbia adopted Bill No. 12-657, on first and second readings, July 7, 1998 and September 22, 1998, respectively. Following the signature of the Mayor on October 16, 1998, pursuant to Section 404(e) of "the Act and was assigned Act No. 12-497 and published in the December 4, 1998, edition of the D.C. Register (Vol. 45 page 8459) and transmitted to Congress on February 3, 1999 for a 30-day review, in accordance with Section 602(c)(1) of the Act. The Council of the District of Columbia hereby gives notice that the 30-day Congressional Review Period has expired, and therefore, cites this enactment as D.C. Law 12-210, effective April 13, 1999. LINDA W CROPP Chairman of the Council Dates Counted During the 30-day Congressional Review Period: Feb. 3,4,8,9,10,11,12,22,23,24,25 Mar. 1,2,3,4,5,8,9,10,11,15,16,17,18,19,22,23,24,25 ENROLLED ORIGINAL AN ACT D,C, ACT 12-497 1N THE COUNCIL OF THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA OCTOBER 16, 1998 Codification District of Columbia Code 1999 Supp. To amend, on a temporary basis, the Medicaid Benefits Protection Act of 1994 to include requirements regarding employee health insurance coverage for a child subject to a support order; to amend the Vital Records Act of 1981 to change the procedures for establishing paternity and require Social Security numbers to be included on certain records and to limit the circumstances under which the name of the father of a non-marital child may be recorded on a birth certificate; to amend Title 16 of the District of Columbia Code to 1) restrict the bases for challenging a paternity adjudication, 2) require specific notice before the signing of a voluntary paternity acknowledgment, 3) permit recision of a voluntary paternity acknowledgment, 4) establish voluntary paternity acknowledgment programs at birthing hospitals and the birth records agency~ 5) authorize the Mayor to establish voluntary paternity acknowledgment programs at other sites, 6) require medical support in all support orders, 7) modify the process for adjusting support orders every 3 years, 8) require the Mayor to establish privacy protections and safeguards for victims of domestic violence, 9) permit paternity adjudications that were barred by prior statutes of limitations, 10) require genetic testing in certain situations, 11) establish responsibility for payment of genetic tests, 12) prohibit ratification of unchallenged acknowledgments, 13) authorize the IV-D agency to obtain paternity acknowledgments, 14) clarify that acknowledgments are admissible in judicial proceedings, 15) allow childbirth, pregnancy, and genetic testing bills to be admitted without foundation testimony, 16) clarify that ex parte hearings are unnecessary before entry of a default paternity adjudication where proof of actual notice regarding any hearing that the putative father failed to attend, 17) clarify that there is no right to a jury trial in paternity proceedings, 18) require that all voluntary acknowledgments of paternity be filed with the Registrar of Vital Records, 19) clarify who may bring a paternity action, 20) require inclusion of Social Security numbers in paternity and support records, and 21) require temporary child support in certain paternity cases; to amend An Act To require premarital examinations in the District of Columbia to require inclusion of Social Security numbers on an application for a marriage license and authorize the IV-D agency to establish a centralized Collection and ENROLLED ORIGINAL Disbursement Unit; to amend the Child Support Enforcement Amendment Act of 1985 to 1) alter the basis for modifying certain support orders, 2) require inclusion of medical support in support orders, 3) mandate notice concerning medical insurance coverage, 4) require notice that all child support orders will be reported to a consumer credit agency, 5) expedite notice in ongoing actions for support, 6) require that such reports be made to credit agencies, 7) require the Collection and Disbursement Unit to enforce medical orders, 8) clarify that hearings are not required before imposition of income withholding, 9) permit the IV-D agency to execute a withholding order without notice, 10) reduce the amount of time before a holder must withhold income, l I) permit application of another state’s income withholding rules in interstate cases, 12) bring time frames for issuing withholding orders to into conformity with federal law, 13) permit liens to arise by operation of law in support cases, 14) provide full faith and credit to other states’ liens, 15) clarify authority to intercept lottery winnings in form of periodic payments, 16) limit liability for holders and those providing information, 17) modify license denial and revocation requirements, 18) require parties to file and update information with the Superior Court and the IV-D agency, 19) grant the IV-D agency certain new powers to expedite paternity and support processes, 20) establish a District of Columbia Directory of New Hires, 21) require reporting to the Directory, and 22) provide access to other states to certain motor vehicle and law enforcement records for child support purposes; to amend the Cable Television Communications Act of 1981 to permit disclosure of certain customer information; to amend An Act Making appropriations to provide for the expenses of the District of Columbia for the fiscal year ending June thirtieth, nineteen- hundred and fourteen to permit disclosure of customer information; to amend the District of Columbia Unemployment Compensation Act to permit disclosure of unemployment information to the agency charged with support or paternity establishment services; to amend Title 47 of the D.C. Code to permit disclosure of income and franchise tax information to the agency that is responsible for the District’s State Plan; and to require inclusion of Social Security numbers on certain license applications; to amend the District of Columbia Traffic Act of 1925 to require that each operator’s permit issued by the District state the social security number of the permittee; and to require financial institutions to conduct data matches with the IV-D agency and to authorize reimbursement to such institutions for reasonable costs.
